_prev_prog_3.Description: The process consists of one ammonia refrigeration system subject to the requirements of OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: City of Amarillo Dept of Emerg Mgmt

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Plains Dairy is a distributor of a variety of bottled drink products to the consumer market at our facility located in Amarillo, Tx. We have a strong commitment to operate our facility in a safe and responsible manner. The SIC code for the operation is 5143; NAICS code is 42443. The facility has approximately 95 full time employees and operates 24 hours/day, 7 days/week, and 52 weeks/year.



Ammonia is used at our facility as the cooling medium in our refrigeration system. The ammonia is contained in a closed loop system; it is designed to remain inside the piping and vessels in our facility.  We believe that ammonia provides the safest and most efficient cooling choice for our operation. 40 CFR 68.130 lists anhydrous ammonia as a hazardous chemical subject to the RMP regulation with a threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs., the refrigeration system exceeds this threshold.



Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Policies 

We take many precautions to prevent or minimize accidental releases of ammonia from the refrigeration system.  These precautions include safety controls (alarms and automatic shutdown devices) which are designed to identify and prevent potentially unsafe conditions like pressure increases that could cause a system failure.  The system emergency shutdown is located outside the engine room and the maintenance office. We also have a preventive maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the systems, a training program designed to ensure that the systems are operated by qualified personnel, and emergency response procedures that enable trained personnel to respond quickly to system upsets. Walking inspections are conducted on intervals not longer than 8 hours. System parameters are logged in a permanent record, as are routine maintenance activities.



The Engineer/Assistant Engineer is responsible for the management of these ammonia safety programs. 



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled 

Ammonia is the only s

ubstance covered by the Accidental Release Prevention Regulations handled at this facility. 



Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program 

The facility has an accident release prevention program that complies with Occupational Safety and Health 

Act's Process Safety Management Standard and EPA's Risk Management Program Rule. The prevention program consists of the following elements: 

?    Employee Participation Program

?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training Program

?    Contractor Safety Program

?    Pre-Startup Safety Review Procedures

?    Mechanical Integrity Program

?    Hot Work Permit Procedures

?    Management of Change Procedures

?    Incident Investigation Procedures

?    Compliance Audit Procedures 



Five-Year Accident History 

No ammonia-related accidents have occurred at the facility over the past five years that resulted in significant onsite or offsite consequences. Facility personnel are trained to safely control small, incidental releases of ammonia, in the event they should occur.

 

 Emergency Action Program 

An emergency action program has been implemented at the facility. This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia spills and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures; section 302 & 303 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act (EPCRA), by notifying the State Emergency Response Commission (SERC), Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and the local Fire Department.  The program has been coordinated with local fire department officials. 

The facility files a Tier 2 Chemical Inventory each year with the SERC, LEPC and the Fire Department as required by sections 311 and 312 of EPCRA.

A release of 100 lbs or more must be reported to the National Response Center, SERC, and LEPC in accordance with section 304 of EPCRA.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

We have identified 2 potential changes to improve the safety of our

ammonia refrigeration system. Increase walking inspections to insure proper operation of equipment. Improve on employee knowledge on the ammonia that is used for cooling of products and work areas at the facility.
